prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Effect of Transfer: Proceedings in the Transferee Court

para.paratext: The Panel has frequently ordered cases transferred for “coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.”[1] It has not, however, ever interfered in the proceedings in the transferee court to suggest which type of management it feels is appropriate. In one case the Panel noted:

The Panel's function under Section 1407 is to decide in the first instance whether to transfer actions for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings. Whether and to what extent the pretrial proceedings in the transferred actions will be coordinated or consolidated is the function of the transferee judge. Clearly the term “coordinated” and the term “consolidated” denote different judicial functions. And we are of the view that a judge deciding whether to consolidate actions for all purposes is necessarily performing a different judicial function than a transferee judge who is supervising coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings under Section 1407. It is for the transferee judge in fashioning a pretrial program that takes into account the different facets and nuances of the litigation to determine what effect to give to [a transferor court order declining to consolidate the transferred actions].[2]
The Panel's deference to the transferee court is fundamental to its limited role in the transfer process, and is grounded in the statute and the statute's legislative history.[3] The Panel has noted:

The statute speaks in terms of transfer to “any district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.” 28 U.S.C. § 1407(a). Used in the disjunctive, the critical words denote different judicial functions. They are indicative of the flexibility and resourcefulness implicit in the legislation. They were undoubtedly intended to confer on a transferee judge the power to fashion the discovery program to accommodate the different facets and nuances of the litigation. It is the province of the Panel to decide whether in the first instance the litigation should be transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings. It is the province of the transferee judge to determine whether and to what extent the pretrial proceedings should be coordinated or consolidated. We have repeatedly declined to attempt to determine in what way and to what extent the litigation should be coordinated or consolidated. From the very beginning we have left that determination to the discretion of the transferee judge.[4]

In addition to recognizing its inability to control the activities and case management decisions of the transferee court, the Panel has deferred considerably to the potential transferee judge in deciding questions relating to transfer. For example, litigants have frequently argued against transfer for consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceedings on the grounds that their action would not benefit from coordination or consolidation. The Panel has generally responded to this argument by ignoring it on the question of transfer and by acknowledging that the transferee court can enter appropriate orders for the management of the transferred cases. In one case the Panel ordered transfer of an action despite that fact that one defendant was a party to only one of the cases to be coordinated or consolidated. The Panel refused to exclude the party's claims from the transfer order, but rather, noted that defendant did not have to participate in pretrial proceedings unrelated to its action and that the transferee court has

broad discretion to design a pretrial program that will allow discovery on any issues unique to [that defendant] to proceed independently of and concurrently with the common pretrial matters …. The transferee judge will have the best vantage point to determine whether the claims against [that defendant] are ready for remand, and if he reaches that conclusion, he may recommend that the Panel remand those claims.[5]

The Panel also has consolidated inherently different claims with the recognition that if common factual issues exist, the transferee court can enter appropriate orders to permit discovery on the common issues to proceed concurrently with the separate discovery.[6] This deference to the broad powers of the transferee court is reflected in numerous decisions of the Panel.[7] The Panel has been especially deferential to the transferee court in matters relating to class actions and potentially conflicting classes. In one early case the Panel stated:

Our experience since [an earlier case] has reinforced our belief that resolution of potentially conflicting class actions are best made by the transferee court …. Such a potential for conflicting or overlapping class actions presents one of the strongest reasons for transferring such related actions to a single district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings which will include an early resolution of such potential conflicts.[8]

The Panel has also declined to consider the effect that bankruptcy proceedings involving a litigant in one action would have on the litigation as a whole, but rather, indicated that matter could be taken up with the transferee court judge.[9] Similarly, the Panel rejected an argument that it should not order transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings because one party was aligned both as a plaintiff and defendant in the various suits. The Panel stated:

We are confident, as we have observed in analogous situations in the past, that any unique discovery needs regarding [that party] and any antagonistic interests among the parties may be accommodated by the transferee judge in designing the pretrial program.[10]

The Panel has also stated that the expertise and experience of the transferee court may be especially worthy of deference in matters relating to tag-along actions.[11] In one case involving two potential tag-along actions and previously transferred litigation, the Panel stated:

In these circumstances, a single judge with an overall perspective of [the tag-along actions] and the previously transferred actions will be in the best position to prevent duplicative discovery, eliminate any possibility of conflicting pretrial rulings and conserve time and effort for the parties, the witnesses and the judiciary. Of course, the transferee judge has the broad discretion to design a pretrial program that will allow discovery on any unique issues in particular actions to proceed concurrently with discovery on common issues.[12]

The Panel has not been willing to defer totally to transferee courts, however. Its transfer decisions have stated a strong preference for the transfer of cases to a district where the broadest, most comprehensive coordination or consolidation can take place.[13] This preference provides subtle, but occasionally blunt, encouragement to transferee courts to take an expansive rather than restrained view of their management role in transferred cases.[14]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
More recently the Panel has simply referred to transfer for “centralized” pretrial proceedings. The meaning and usage of the two phrases by the Panel appear interchangeable.
